etymology.description: semantic: 爫 ‘hand, claw’ + 又 ‘hand’ (middle component varied historically)
etymology.interpretation: Two hands suggest an action of grasping or taking, an image that later extended to a connective meaning marking a resulting action or step. From the notion of taking something in hand comes the sense of ‘thereupon/therefore’ in classical usage.

examples.chinese: 王师既定齐地，爰告庙(王師既定齊地，爰告廟)。
examples.pinyin: Wáng shī jì dìng Qí dì, yuán gào miào.
examples.english: After the royal army pacified the Qi territory, thereupon they reported at the ancestral temple.

examples.chinese: 天雨方霁，爰出行(天雨方霽，爰出行)。
examples.pinyin: Tiān yǔ fāng jì, yuán chūxíng.
examples.english: The rain had just cleared; therefore we set out.

examples.chinese: 君子知义，爰从之(君子知義，爰從之)。
examples.pinyin: Jūnzǐ zhī yì, yuán cóng zhī.
examples.english: A gentleman understands righteousness; accordingly he follows it.
